results_summary: Kaempferol significantly reduced NLRP3-ASC/TMS1-Caspase 3 expression in liver tissue and decreased lipid droplet accumulation in HepG2 cells, suggesting therapeutic potential for NASH by targeting inflammation and lipid metabolism.
population_specificity: C57BL/6 female mice and HepG2 cell model.
effective_dosage: 20 mg/kg per day (in vivo), 20 µM and 20 nM (in vitro).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop and evaluate a nanomedicine-based therapeutic strategy using Kaempferol-loaded nanoparticles to alleviate Postoperative Neurocognitive Disorder (PND).
results_summary: The study found that pDA/KAE@ZIF-8 nanoparticles efficiently penetrated the blood-brain barrier, protected neuronal cells from oxidative stress, reduced inflammation, and significantly improved cognitive functions in a PND mouse model, outperforming Kaempferol alone.
population_specificity: Elderly patients undergoing surgery (tested in a PND mouse model).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify and characterize bitter and astringent kaempferol glucosides in rapeseed protein isolates and assess their impact on TAS2R-linked proton secretion and bitter receptor expression.
results_summary: The study identified eight additional bitter and astringent kaempferol glucosides in rapeseed protein isolates, with varying taste thresholds. Compounds 1 and 8 increased mRNA levels of multiple bitter receptors (TAS2Rs) and influenced proton secretion in HGT-1 cells. Some compounds exceeded dose-over-threshold factors for bitterness and astringency in protein isolates, and a potential precursor for the key bitter compound was identified.
population_specificity: Human sensory experiments (taste thresholds) and in vitro HGT-1 cell analysis.
effective_dosage: Taste threshold concentrations ranged from 3.3 to 531.7 μmol/L (bitterness) and 0.3 to 66.4 μmol/L (astringency).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of hyaluronic acid-coated gelatin nanoparticles loaded with Kaempferol (HA-KM GNP) for treating knee osteoarthritis by assessing its anti-inflammatory and chondrogenic properties.
results_summary: HA-KM GNP significantly reduced inflammatory markers (IL-1β, TNF-α, COX-2, MMP-9, MMP-13) and upregulated SOX9 in IL-1β-stimulated chondrocytes, while in vivo results showed reduced OA severity, improved cartilage thickness, and attenuated inflammation in an ACLT-induced rat model.
population_specificity: Rat chondrocytes and ACLT-induced knee osteoarthritis rat model.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the role of kaempferol in gastrointestinal cancer treatment and explore how nanotechnology enhances its therapeutic efficacy.
results_summary: Kaempferol inhibits cancer progression by altering molecular pathways (PI3/Akt, mTOR, Erk/MAPK), reducing cell proliferation, survival, angiogenesis, and metastasis. Nano formulations improve its bioavailability and efficacy, though more in vivo and clinical research is needed.
population_specificity: Gastrointestinal cancer research (in vitro and potential clinical implications).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the sources, bioavailability, and role of Kaempferol in various pathogenesis, as well as its potential health benefits and mechanisms of action.
results_summary: Kaempferol exhibits antioxidant, anti-inflammatory, cardioprotective, neuroprotective, hepatoprotective, and anti-diabetic properties, and may inhibit tumor growth. It shows increased efficacy when combined with other compounds or in nano-formulations. Further research is needed on its toxicity and safety.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro and in vivo studies referenced, but no human population detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize the pharmacological advances of Kaempferol in treating metabolic diseases and explore its potential molecular mechanisms of action.
results_summary: Kaempferol demonstrated remarkable therapeutic effects on metabolic diseases by regulating multiple signaling pathways, including NF-κB, Nrf2, AMPK, PI3K/AKT, TLR4, and ER stress. The review also discussed its natural sources, pharmacokinetics, and safety profile, supporting its potential as a treatment candidate.
population_specificity: Not specified (general metabolic disease focus, including diabetes, obesity, NAFLD/NASH, and atherosclerosis).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the protective effects of kaempferol 3-sophoroside-7-glucoside (KSG) against acute lung injury (ALI) in mice, comparing its efficacy to dexamethasone.
results_summary: KSG effectively protected mice from LPS-induced ALI, reducing lung damage, inflammation, and oxidative stress while enhancing antioxidant activity. It also demonstrated strong binding affinity to KEAP1, activating Nrf2 and suppressing inflammatory pathways.
population_specificity: Mice with LPS-induced acute lung injury.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify active flavonoid compounds in Vernonia anthelmintica, particularly kaempferol, and evaluate its potential therapeutic effects against oxidative stress damage in keratinocytes.
results_summary: Kaempferol enhanced HaCaT cell viability, inhibited apoptosis, reduced oxidative stress markers (MDA and ROS), and upregulated antioxidant gene expression (HO-1, GCLC, GCLM, Nrf2, NQO1, Keap1), demonstrating significant protection against oxidative damage.
population_specificity: In vitro study using HaCaT keratinocyte cells.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to demonstrate Kaempferol's therapeutic potential for gastrointestinal tumors (GC) and elucidate its underlying mechanisms.
results_summary: Kaempferol promoted NLRP3 inflammatory vesicle activation via the NF-κB pathway, leading to Caspase-1 cleavage and IL-18 release, and induced pyroptosis in AGS cells through mitochondrial damage.
population_specificity: AGS cells (a gastric adenocarcinoma cell line)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate Kaempferol's potential to mitigate inflammatory processes in diabetic retinopathy by targeting immune cell responses, particularly microglia-mediated anti-inflammatory effects.
results_summary: Kaempferol significantly reduced inflammation in in vitro, ex vivo, and in vivo diabetic retinopathy models, primarily by inhibiting proinflammatory responses and promoting an anti-inflammatory environment through microglial synthesis of Arginase-1 and Hemeoxygenase-1 (HO-1). It also preserved retinal integrity in vivo.
population_specificity: BB rats (a Type 1 Diabetes animal model) and HAPI microglial and J774.A1 macrophage cells.
effective_dosage: Not specified (intraperitoneal injections administered for 15 days).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify the chemicals in T. hemsleyanum responsible for its antipyretic effects and explain its traditional use for fever treatment.
results_summary: Kaempferol 3-rutinoside (K3OR) was isolated from T. hemsleyanum and showed significant antipyretic effects in a mouse model, outperforming ibuprofen and acetaminophen at 4 μM. K3OR modulated IL-6 and TNF-α levels, suggesting a regulatory role in fever.
population_specificity: Mouse model of fever induced by lipopolysaccharide (LPS).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the mechanisms by which kaempferol inhibits mast cell activation and whether it suppresses hippocampal mast cell activation in LPS-induced depressive mice.
results_summary: Kaempferol significantly decreased TNF-α expression and secretion, inhibited NFAT transcriptional activity and nuclear translocation, suppressed SOCE-mediated Ca2+ influx, and reversed LPS-induced depression-like behaviors in mice by inhibiting hippocampal mast cell activation.
population_specificity: Human mast cells (HMC-1) in vitro and LPS-induced depressive mice in vivo.
effective_dosage: Not specified for kaempferol in the abstract.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to elucidate the anti-hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) effects of kaempferol derived from A. officinarum and explore its underlying mechanistic pathways.
results_summary: Kaempferol significantly inhibited HCC cell proliferation, migration, and tumor spheroid growth, induced G2/M arrest, and promoted apoptosis by regulating the ATM/CHEK2/KNL1 pathway. Bioinformatics analysis linked high expression of pathway-related genes to poor HCC prognosis.
population_specificity: HCCLM3 and Huh7 cell lines (in vitro study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how Kaempferol induces browning of white adipose tissue and its potential role in treating obesity through the AMPK/SIRT1/PGC-1α pathway.
results_summary: Kaempferol-treated mice showed reduced diet-induced obesity, improved glucose tolerance and insulin resistance, and increased expression of thermogenesis-related proteins. The browning effect was linked to the AMPK/SIRT1/PGC-1α pathway, as inhibition of AMPK partially reversed the browning phenotype.
population_specificity: Obese mice and primary adipocytes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to improve the bioavailability and reduce side effects of Kaempferol by developing a novel liposomal codelivery system (DTM@KA NPs) for treating severe acute pancreatitis (SAP).
results_summary: The study found that DTM@KA NPs improved mitochondrial and redox homeostasis, reduced inflammation and apoptosis, and enhanced ATP supply in SAP, with negligible side effects. The thioketals (TK) modification was crucial for enhancing Kaempferol's efficacy.
population_specificity: Severe acute pancreatitis (SAP) models (in vitro and in vivo).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the effects and mechanisms of Kaempferol (KPR) on LPS-induced inflammatory responses in human gallbladder epithelial cells (HGBECs) as a potential treatment for cholecystitis.
results_summary: KPR increased cell viability in LPS-induced HGBECs, reduced inflammatory markers (IL-1β, IL-6, TNF-α), and inhibited the MAPK/NF-κB signaling pathway, suggesting anti-inflammatory effects. The optimal intervention concentration was 50 μM, which did not significantly affect cell viability or LDH levels.
population_specificity: Human gallbladder epithelial cells (HGBECs) in vitro.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate kaempferol's potential in preventing and treating osteoporosis by identifying core targets and pathways through network pharmacology and validating findings with molecular experiments.
results_summary: The study identified 54 overlapping targets between kaempferol and osteoporosis, with 10 core targets, and validated kaempferol's upregulation of AKT1 and downregulation of MMP9 in MC3T3-E1 cells, suggesting therapeutic potential.
population_specificity: In vitro study using MC3T3-E1 cells (osteoblast-like cells).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect and mechanism of kaempferol on alcoholic steatohepatitis, focusing on its impact on gut barrier function and inflammatory response.
results_summary: Kaempferol improved liver tissue pathology, reduced inflammatory markers (ALT, AST, IL-1β, TNF-α), and enhanced gut barrier stability by targeting miR-155 and increasing occludin and SOCS1 protein expression. It also reduced serum LPS levels and inhibited nuclear factor kappa-B activation in both in vivo and in vitro models.
population_specificity: C57BL/6 N mice and intestinal epithelial Caco-2 cells.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to reveal the mechanism by which kaempferol inhibits colorectal cancer (CRC) progression and regulates the JMJD2C/β-catenin signalling pathway.
results_summary: Kaempferol inhibited CRC cell migration by reducing JMJD2C/β-catenin signalling activation, mediated through miR-205-5p and circ_0000345. It also suppressed CRC lung metastasis in vivo by binding to HNRNPK and HNRNPL, downregulating circ_0000345.
population_specificity: Colorectal cancer cells (in vitro) and a pulmonary metastatic CRC model (in vivo).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Kaempferol could alleviate obesity-induced inflammation and insulin resistance by modulating the STING/NLRP3 signaling pathway in leptin receptor-deficient obese mice.
results_summary: Kaempferol treatment significantly reduced body weight, fat mass, and adipocyte size, improved glucose tolerance and insulin resistance, and reduced macrophage infiltration and inflammatory markers in adipose tissue. It also inhibited the STING/NLRP3 signaling pathway in vivo and suppressed LPS-induced inflammation in vitro.
population_specificity: Leptin receptor-deficient obese mice (db/db) as an insulin-resistant model.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the existing literature on kaempferol's neuroprotective effects in various neurological diseases, including stroke, Parkinson's disease, Alzheimer's disease, and others.
results_summary: Kaempferol demonstrated antioxidant, anti-inflammatory, and antiapoptotic properties, modulating key signaling pathways like PI3K/Akt and NF-κB, enhancing neuronal survival, reducing oxidative stress, and improving cognitive function. The evidence suggests kaempferol holds promise for preventing and treating neurological diseases.
population_specificity: In vitro and in vivo models (not specified if human or animal).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the potential mechanisms and therapeutic effects of metformin combined with kaempferol on postmenopausal osteoporosis.
results_summary: The study found that kaempferol alone and in combination with metformin improved bone microstructure, density, and mechanical properties in ovariectomy-induced osteoporosis rats, enhanced bone formation markers, and promoted osteogenesis-angiogenesis coupling without hepatotoxicity or nephrotoxicity. The combination also upregulated angiogenesis-related markers and activated the Notch intracellular pathway in vitro.
population_specificity: Ovariectomy-induced osteoporosis rats and in vitro models (RAW264.7 cells, MC3T3-E1 cells, HUVECs).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore kaempferol's therapeutic effect on lung cancer, its ability to regulate gut microbiota, and its stimulation of immune function.
results_summary: Kaempferol significantly inhibited lung cancer growth in mice, activated immune cells (cytotoxic T cells and NK cells), and increased beneficial gut microbiota species.
population_specificity: BALB/c mice (normal and Lewis Lung Carcinoma-inoculated)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether kaempferol (KMF) could protect against bisphenol A (BPA)-induced reproductive toxicity in male rats by examining its effects on testosterone levels, oxidative stress, and tissue damage.
results_summary: KMF treatment increased cell viability, restored testosterone levels, reduced oxidative stress, and ameliorated BPA-induced tissue damage in testis and prostate tissues. The study suggests KMF has protective effects against BPA's harmful reproductive impacts.
population_specificity: Adult male Wistar rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential therapeutic effects of kaempferol (KMP) on various types of solid malignant tumors through a systematic review.
results_summary: The study found that KMP demonstrated antitumor effects by influencing tumor cell cycle progression, proliferation, apoptosis, migration, invasion, and angiogenesis inhibition. It also enhanced the sensitivity of cancer cells to traditional chemotherapy drugs like cisplatin and 5-fluorouracil.
population_specificity: In vitro studies (cell lines) and preclinical research on solid malignant tumors.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the mechanisms by which kaempferol attenuates sepsis-related ARDS using network pharmacology and experimental verification.
results_summary: Kaempferol was found to reduce inflammatory response, ROS production, and cell apoptosis by blocking the HIF-1, NF-κB, and PI3K-Akt signaling pathways, thereby alleviating sepsis-related ARDS in LPS-induced murine alveolar macrophage cells.
population_specificity: Murine alveolar macrophage (MH-S) cells induced by lipopolysaccharide (LPS).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate Kaempferol's potential as an adjunctive therapy to 5-FU in mitigating adverse effects and enhancing treatment efficacy in a DMH-induced colorectal cancer animal model.
results_summary: Kaempferol demonstrated hemato-protective and immunomodulatory effects, counteracted 5-FU-induced damage, and preserved the structural integrity of the intestine and spleen. It also ameliorated liver injury and mitigated CRC-induced renal impairment.
population_specificity: DMH-induced colorectal cancer animal model (rats or mice, not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the potential synergy between doxorubicin and Kaempferol in reducing tumor volume and modulating cancer-related gene expression in an Ehrlich tumor mice model.
results_summary: Kaempferol, when combined with doxorubicin, was effective against Ehrlich solid tumors, but the combination with Piperlongumine-loaded chitosan nanoparticles showed significantly enhanced anticancer effects compared to Kaempferol or the same free compounds.
population_specificity: Albino mice with Ehrlich ascites carcinoma-induced solid tumors.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether kaempferol could mitigate male reproductive toxicity induced by Naja nigricollis venom in rats.
results_summary: Kaempferol treatment normalized reproductive hormone levels, improved sperm functional parameters, and reduced oxidative stress and inflammatory biomarkers in envenomed rats. It also ameliorated histopathological damage in testicular and epididymal tissues.
population_specificity: Male Wistar rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the anticancer effects of kaempferol on human oral cancer MC-3 cells, focusing on apoptosis and autophagy mechanisms.
results_summary: Kaempferol reduced MC-3 cell survival, induced intrinsic apoptosis, and altered autophagy-related protein expression in vitro, while also reducing tumor growth via apoptosis and autophagy in vivo. Autophagy inhibitors revealed a cytoprotective effect on apoptosis in kaempferol-treated cells.
population_specificity: Human oral cancer MC-3 cells (in vitro) and a xenograft model (in vivo).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if RPN1 is a target for kaempferol in treating osteoporosis and to explore its biological and immune mechanisms.
results_summary: Kaempferol showed high binding affinity to RPN1, improved bone microstructure, and reversed RPN1 overexpression in ovariectomized rats, suggesting its potential efficacy in osteoporosis treatment.
population_specificity: Ovariectomized rats (animal model for osteoporosis)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the protective mechanism of kaempferol and nicotiflorin on alcohol-induced liver injury, focusing on oxidative stress, lipid metabolism, and gut microbiota regulation.
results_summary: Kaempferol significantly reduced alcohol-induced liver damage by lowering oxidative stress markers (MDA, CYP2E1) and enhancing antioxidant activity (SOD, GSH). It also regulated gut microbiota and modulated signaling pathways (miR-138-5p/SIRT1/FXR) to improve lipid metabolism and oxidative stress.
population_specificity: Forty mice with alcohol-induced liver injury.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Kaempferol could mitigate lead (Pb)-induced cognitive deficits and neuronal damage by investigating its effects on autophagy and synaptic protein expression.
results_summary: Kaempferol improved learning and memory abilities, reduced hippocampal neuronal damage, and reversed Pb-induced synaptic protein (PSD95 and NMDAR2B) deficits by inhibiting excessive autophagy activation.
population_specificity: Pb-exposed rats (postnatal day 30 to 60).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the antiviral ability of kaempferol against channel catfish virus (CCV) infection in vitro.
results_summary: Kaempferol exhibited the strongest inhibitory effect against CCV among tested compounds, reducing viral gene transcription, protein synthesis, and viral progeny release in a dose-dependent manner. It likely blocks viral attachment and internalization during the entry process.
population_specificity: In vitro cell models (not specified for human or animal in vivo use).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether kaempferol, alone or combined with vitamin E, could protect against lead acetate-induced testicular toxicity in male rats.
results_summary: Kaempferol, especially when combined with vitamin E, significantly improved antioxidant enzyme levels, reduced oxidative stress markers, enhanced sperm function, and upregulated key reproductive hormones and gene expressions compared to the lead-exposed group. The combination also showed anti-inflammatory effects and improved testicular regeneration.
population_specificity: Adult male rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the anticancer effects of kaempferol on gynaecological malignancies and provide a systematic analysis of its mechanism of action.
results_summary: Kaempferol demonstrated potential anti-tumour effects, including inducing apoptosis, inhibiting proliferation, and preventing metastasis in breast, ovarian, and endometrial cancers, though more research is needed to confirm efficacy.
population_specificity: Gynaecological malignancies (breast, ovarian, and endometrial cancers)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to uncover the mechanism of action of kaempferol in treating cervical cancer using metabolomics and network pharmacology.
results_summary: Kaempferol was associated with 11 differential metabolites and 7 metabolic pathways, including arginine and proline metabolism and the tricarboxylic acid cycle. It also regulated 3 metabolites by targeting 7 specific proteins, with strong molecular docking affinities.
population_specificity: Cervical cancer (specific human population not detailed in abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the molecular mechanisms of kaempferol, stellasterin, and quercetin in treating tissue hypoxia in patients with viral and bacterial pneumonia.
results_summary: The combination of kaempferol, stellasterin, and quercetin increased total ATPase activity in pneumonia patients with respiratory insufficiency compared to baseline and placebo, suggesting potential benefits in managing hypoxia and inflammation.
population_specificity: 110 individuals with viral and bacterial pneumonia, divided into placebo and Panax phytopreparation groups.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the synergistic effects of co-encapsulated astaxanthin/kaempferol nanoparticles on reducing oxidative stress, inflammation, and lipid accumulation in cell lines.
results_summary: The nanoparticles enhanced inhibition of oxidative stress in HepG2 cells and reduced LPS-induced NO production in RAW264.7 cells, along with lowering inflammation-related gene expression and lipid content in hepatocytes.
population_specificity: RAW264.7 and HepG2 cell lines.
study_duration: Not specified for intervention, but stability was assessed over 6 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the influence of Kaempferol on adrenic acid's regulatory role in pathophysiological processes and its potential as a therapeutic target.
results_summary: The study found that Kaempferol influences adrenic acid, which plays a role in inflammatory reactions, lipid metabolism, oxidative stress, vascular function, and cell death, suggesting potential therapeutic benefits. However, the specific molecular mechanisms remain unclear.
population_specificity: Not specified (general pathophysiological processes across multiple systems).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the efficacy of herbal bioactive compounds, including kaempferol, for cardiovascular disease therapy using computational and in silico studies.
results_summary: Kaempferol was identified as a bioactive compound with potential anti-CVD traits, primarily through mechanisms like cell signaling, inflammation inhibition, oxidative stress reduction, and lipid accumulation decrease. However, its effects were not confirmed by in vitro, in vivo, or clinical trials in this study.
population_specificity: Not specified (computational/in silico study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify key biomarkers of depressive disorder (DD) and explore the potential mechanism of Passiflora's antidepressant effects, including the role of Kaempferol as one of its active ingredients.
results_summary: The study identified Kaempferol as a key active ingredient of Passiflora, linked to neuro-inflammatory signaling pathways (IL-17, TNF, NF-kappa B) and neurotransmitter function, suggesting a potential role in DD treatment. However, direct efficacy data for Kaempferol alone were not provided.
population_specificity: Depressive disorder (DD) samples (specific human or animal model not detailed in the abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify the main components and targets of Danggui Sini Decoction (DSD), including Kaempferol, in treating myocardial infarction (MI) using network pharmacology and molecular docking.
results_summary: The study found that Kaempferol, along with other compounds in DSD, may interact with key targets like AKT1, EGFR, TP53, and TNF, potentially contributing to MI treatment through multi-component, multi-pathway mechanisms.
population_specificity: Not specified (in silico study using databases and molecular docking).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the neuroprotective effects of kaempferol, focusing on its mechanisms and key signaling pathways in treating neurodegenerative diseases.
results_summary: The study found that kaempferol exhibits neuroprotective effects through anti-inflammatory, anti-oxidative stress, regulation of autophagy, inhibition of apoptosis, and promotion of neuronal regeneration. It highlights its potential in improving symptoms and delaying progression of neurodegenerative diseases.
population_specificity: Not specified (review of existing research, not a clinical trial).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the therapeutic potential and side effects of various chemical groups, including flavonoids like Kaempferol, to determine their suitability for medical applications.
results_summary: The study found that Kaempferol, among flavonoids, showed higher medical utilization with lower side effects compared to other chemical groups like alkaloids, which had the lowest medical use and highest side effects. Kaempferol and quercetin were highly recommended for a wide range of medical applications due to their favorable safety and efficacy profiles.
population_specificity: Not specified (general comparison of chemical groups).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the wound-healing properties of five Bulbine species, including the presence and effects of kaempferol glucoside, using in vitro and in vivo models.
results_summary: Kaempferol glucoside was identified in four of the five Bulbine species, and the extracts showed non-cytotoxic effects on keratinocytes. B. abyssinica demonstrated significant wound-closure improvement in vitro, while B. frutescens showed the highest regeneration in vivo.
population_specificity: Zebrafish larvae and HaCaT cell monolayers (in vitro and in vivo models).
study_duration: 48 hours (in vitro), up to 36 hours post-treatment (in vitro), and three days post fertilization (in vivo).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the molecular mechanism of Xiaojian Zhongtang (XJZT), including kaempferol, in treating major depressive disorder (MDD) using network pharmacology and bioinformatics.
results_summary: Kaempferol was identified as a core chemical component of XJZT, interacting with key targets (AKT1, DRD4, KMO) implicated in MDD pathways. The study suggests kaempferol may regulate these targets, contributing to XJZT's therapeutic effects on MDD.
population_specificity: Not specified (in silico and bioinformatics analysis, no human or animal subjects mentioned).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to elucidate the mechanisms of Yiyi Tongfeng Formula (YTF), including kaempferol, in treating acute gouty arthritis (AGA) using network pharmacology and molecular docking.
results_summary: The study identified kaempferol as a potential main active component of YTF for AGA treatment, suggesting its involvement in inflammatory responses and signaling pathways like IL-17 and TNF. The findings indicate a multi-faceted therapeutic approach.
population_specificity: Not specified (in silico study using databases and molecular docking).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify the active ingredients of Dahuang Mudan Decoction, including kaempferol, and their potential therapeutic targets for treating acute pancreatitis.
results_summary: Kaempferol was identified as one of the main active components of Dahuang Mudan Decoction, targeting key proteins like AKT1, TNF-a, and IL-6, and acting through pathways such as PI3K-Akt signaling to treat acute pancreatitis. Meta-analysis supported the clinical efficacy of the decoction, which includes kaempferol, in improving treatment outcomes.
population_specificity: Patients with acute pancreatitis (based on meta-analysis of 13 studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the mechanism of Tiaoqi Xiaowei decoction, including Kaempferol, in treating chronic atrophic gastritis using network pharmacology and molecular docking.
results_summary: Kaempferol was identified as a core active component in Tiaoqi Xiaowei decoction, interacting with key targets like AKT1, TP53, and TNF to regulate inflammatory responses and tumor-related signaling pathways. Molecular docking confirmed favorable binding affinity between Kaempferol and these targets.
population_specificity: Chronic atrophic gastritis (in silico study, no human or animal subjects specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and pharmacological mechanisms of Guizhi Fuling Pill (GZFL), including its key active compound kaempferol, in treating ischemic stroke.
results_summary: Kaempferol, as a key active compound in GZFL, demonstrated good affinity with core target proteins and contributed to anti-inflammatory, anti-atherosclerosis, and neuroprotective effects, improving clinical outcomes like NIHSS score and inflammatory markers.
population_specificity: Patients with ischemic stroke (specific demographics not detailed in the abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the clinical efficacy and molecular mechanism of Danhong injection (containing Kaempferol) in treating idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF).
results_summary: Kaempferol was identified as a core active component of Danhong injection, which improved clinical efficiency, lung function, and inflammatory markers in IPF patients. The study also highlighted key targets and pathways, such as PI3K-Akt signaling, through which Kaempferol may exert its effects.
population_specificity: Patients with idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore Kaempferol's potential as an anti-inflammatory agent targeting dysregulated inflammatory pathways in COVID-19.
results_summary: The abstract suggests Kaempferol may modulate inflammatory cascades linked to cytokine storm syndrome in COVID-19, but specific efficacy data are not provided. The study implies potential benefits but lacks detailed results.
population_specificity: Not specified (implied relevance to COVID-19 patients).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the potential of Kaempferol, as a component of M. oleifera, in reducing inflammatory responses and complications related to COVID-19 and cancer progression.
results_summary: The study suggests that Kaempferol, along with other polyphenols in M. oleifera, modulates inflammatory pathways (NF-κB, MAPK, mTOR, NLRP3 inflammasome) and may help mitigate COVID-19 severity and cancer progression, though further research is needed.
population_specificity: Cancer patients with COVID-19 (theoretical focus, not a clinical trial).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate Kaempferol's chemical properties, safety profile, pharmacokinetics, and therapeutic potential against aging-related diseases (ARDs).
results_summary: Kaempferol demonstrated antioxidative, anti-inflammatory, and anti-apoptotic properties, effectively countering oxidative stress and inflammation linked to ARDs. It also showed neuroprotective and anticancer effects through modulation of key cellular pathways.
population_specificity: Preclinical and clinical studies (specific population not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the mechanism of the Zhenbao pill (ZBP), including Kaempferol, in treating spinal cord injury (SCI) by identifying active ingredients, targets, and pathways.
results_summary: Kaempferol was identified as one of the top 5 active ingredients in ZBP, showing good binding ability with core genes (CTNNB1, SRC, TP53, AKT1, STAT3) and involvement in multiple pathways, including PI3K-Akt signaling, suggesting a multi-target, multi-pathway mechanism for SCI treatment.
population_specificity: Not specified (in silico and database analysis)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the efficacy, safety, and mechanism of NYPF therapy (including Kaempferol as a key component) for treating central precocious puberty (CPP).
results_summary: Kaempferol was identified as a key component of the core herb pair in NYPF therapy, which showed efficacy in improving clinical outcomes and reducing serum sex hormone levels in CPP patients. The therapy was deemed safe with no obvious adverse events.
population_specificity: Children with central precocious puberty (CPP).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the potential role of kaempferol, among other flavonoids, in mitigating idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF) by examining its anti-inflammatory, antioxidant, and anti-fibrotic properties.
results_summary: Kaempferol was reported to exhibit anti-inflammatory and antioxidant effects, which may help reduce lung fibrosis by modulating oxidative stress, inflammation, and fibrotic processes. However, challenges such as poor solubility and bioavailability were noted, prompting exploration of novel formulations to enhance efficacy.
population_specificity: Preclinical studies (in vivo and cell line models) focusing on pulmonary fibrosis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the efficacy and safety of traditional Chinese medicine decoction (TCMD) for gouty arthritis (GA), including the role of active ingredients like kaempferol in targeting GA-related pathways.
results_summary: Kaempferol was identified as one of the top-ranked active ingredients in TCMD, associated with cross-targets like AKT1, TNF, and TP53, and signaling pathways such as IL-17 and PI3K-AKT, suggesting potential efficacy in modulating GA-related inflammation and metabolic pathways.
population_specificity: Patients with gouty arthritis (7151 participants across 84 studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy, safety, and underlying mechanisms of GSZD, including Kaempferol, for treating gouty arthritis.
results_summary: Kaempferol was identified as a core active ingredient in GSZD, contributing to improved clinical efficiency, reduced inflammation, and lower uric acid levels in gouty arthritis patients. Molecular docking suggested potential interactions with key targets like AKT1 and TNF-α.
population_specificity: Patients with gouty arthritis (1,633 participants across 20 studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the therapeutic mechanisms of Kaempferol and other bioactive components in the Radix Bupleuri and Radix Paeoniae Alba herb-pair (RRH) for treating hepatitis, focusing on targets and signaling pathways.
results_summary: The study identified Kaempferol as a main bioactive component in RRH, binding to key disease targets (e.g., RELA, AKT1, JUN) and potentially contributing to anti-hepatitis effects through multiple signaling pathways. Molecular docking confirmed spatial and energy matching, suggesting a plausible mechanism for Kaempferol's role in hepatitis treatment.
population_specificity: Not specified (in silico and network pharmacology study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore Kaempferol's potential as an inhibitor of aerobic glycolysis in cervical cancer and its regulatory mechanisms.
results_summary: Kaempferol was found to inhibit key glycolytic enzymes in cervical cancer through signaling pathways like PI3K/AKT/HIF-1α and JAK2/STAT3, suggesting its potential as a therapeutic agent. The abstract highlights its inhibitory effects but does not provide detailed efficacy data.
population_specificity: Cervical cancer (in vitro or in vivo context not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify the active components of XTSJF, including Kaempferol, and elucidate its molecular mechanisms against gastric cancer.
results_summary: Kaempferol was identified as one of the key active components in XTSJF, showing strong affinity with key targets (TP53, MAPK3, MAPK1, STAT3, AKT1) and involvement in regulating signaling pathways (TNF, PI3K-Akt, MAPK) for gastric cancer treatment.
population_specificity: In silico (computational) study, no human or animal subjects specified.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the active components and mechanism of Jiaotai Pill, including kaempferol, in treating primary insomnia by analyzing gene expression and molecular docking.
results_summary: Kaempferol was identified as a core active component of Jiaotai Pill with good docking activity to related differential genes, suggesting its potential role in regulating inflammatory factors to treat primary insomnia.
population_specificity: Primary insomnia patients (specific demographics not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the potential mechanism of Kaempferol in Gegen Qinlian decoction (GGQL) for treating COVID-19 comorbid with diabetes mellitus (DM) using network pharmacology and molecular docking.
results_summary: Kaempferol in GGQL was found to modulate targets like AR, GSK3B, DPP4, F2, and NOS3, potentially affecting pathways related to COVID-19, diabetic complications, and immune response. Molecular docking indicated strong binding activity between Kaempferol and key targets.
population_specificity: COVID-19 patients comorbid with diabetes mellitus (theoretical study, no human subjects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the neurological roles of flavonoids, including kaempferol, in Parkinson's Disease (PD), focusing on their potential therapeutic effects.
results_summary: The study found that kaempferol and other flavonoids exhibit therapeutic potential for PD by protecting dopaminergic neurons, improving motor and cognitive abilities, regulating signaling pathways, and modulating oxidative stress and neuro-inflammation. Additionally, flavonoids may influence gut microbiota composition, reducing pathogenic strains and promoting beneficial ones.
population_specificity: Not specified (general focus on neurodegenerative diseases, particularly PD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the pharmacological activities of Ginkgo Folium, including kaempferol, and its potential therapeutic benefits for cancer patients.
results_summary: Kaempferol, a major flavonoid in Ginkgo Folium, demonstrated antitumor effects by inducing apoptosis, cell cycle arrest, autophagy, and inhibiting invasion and metastasis through modulation of multiple signaling pathways. Synergistic effects were observed with other constituents like quercetin.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro or in vivo studies implied but not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify the active chemical components and molecular mechanisms of Jishe Qushi capsules (JSQS) in treating rheumatoid arthritis (RA), with kaempferol as one of the key components.
results_summary: Kaempferol, found in Radix Paeoniae Alba, was identified as a main active chemical component in JSQS, contributing to its anti-RA effects through multiple pathways, including MAPK signaling. Clinical results showed significant improvements in RA symptoms and biomarkers in the treatment group compared to controls.
population_specificity: 99 patients with rheumatoid arthritis (49 in the treatment group, 50 in the control group).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the pharmacological mechanism of Kaempferol in Taohong Siwu Decoction (THSWD) for treating varicocele-associated male infertility using network pharmacology and molecular docking.
results_summary: Kaempferol showed good intercalation with major targets in molecular docking, suggesting its potential role in regulating inflammatory response, reactive oxygen species damage, and blood vessel function through pathways like HIF-1, PI3K-Akt, Relaxin, and TNF signaling.
population_specificity: Varicocele-associated male infertility (in silico study, no human or animal subjects).
